measurement_remarks: With only a few Mycopsylla individuals collected from F. watkinsiana, it is difficult to draw strong conclusions, but, given the high host specificity of M. fici and M. proxima and the absence of homotomids from other Ficus species we surveyed, it seems likely that this putative new Mycopsylla sp. is specific to F. watkinsiana.

measurement_remarks: Psylloids were collected from one sample of foliage per mistletoe plant or eucalypt tree.
methods: Insects were collected using a restricted canopy fogging technique (after Basset 1990), from plants of A. miquelii (n = 30) and three of its host tree species: E. polyanthemos (red box, n = 12), Eucalyptus melliodora (yellow box, n = 4) and Eucalyptus blakelyi (Blakely’s red gum, n = 3) using a trailer-mounted hydraulic bucket hoist (maximum height: 12 m above ground).
site_name: south-west slopes region of NSW (near Holbrook)
site_description: Woodland and forest have been extensively cleared for agriculture and remaining habitat is restricted to a series of disjunct remnants. At five sites of remnant grassy box woodland, 4–18 hectares in size and located 2–23 km apart (i.e. sites 1–5 in Burns et al. 2011). These sites were surrounded by grazed pastures or crops on privately owned land. The remnant woodlands were dominated by Eucalyptus polyanthemos (red box), which is the primary host of A. miquelii in the region. At least 40 individual A. miquelii occurred at each site.
associated_plant_taxa: Eucalyptus polyanthemos, Eucalyptus melliodora, Eucalyptus blakelyi, Amyema miquelii
plant_relation_description: host plant species; Amyema miquelii on Eucalyptus polyanthemos; Amyema miquelii is the significant (p<0.05) indicated host of the psylloid species, based on the abundance (density of individuals per square-metre leaf area) (n=30) and frequency of the species in the mistletoe and eucalypt samples (n=19).
source_citation: Burns, A. E., Taylor, G. S., Watson, D. M., & Cunningham, S. A. (2015). Diversity and host specificity of Psylloidea (Hemiptera) inhabiting box mistletoe, Amyema miquelii (Loranthaceae) and three of its host Eucalyptus species. Austral Entomology, 54(3), 306–314. doi: 10.1111/aen.12123

site_description: Woodland and forest have been extensively cleared for agriculture and remaining habitat is restricted to a series of disjunct remnants. At five sites of remnant grassy box woodland, 4–18 hectares in size and located 2–23 km apart (i.e. sites 1–5 in Burns et al. 2011). These sites were surrounded by grazed pastures or crops on privately owned land. The remnant woodlands were dominated by Eucalyptus polyanthemos (red box), which is the primary host of A. miquelii in the region. At least 40 individual A. miquelii occurred at each site.
associated_plant_taxa: Eucalyptus polyanthemos, Eucalyptus melliodora, Amyema miquelii
plant_relation_description: host plant species; No particular host plant species preference for the psylloid species, as demonstrated by no significance (p>0.05) in indicated host of the psylloid species, based on the abundance (density of individuals per square-metre leaf area) and frequency of the species in the mistletoe and eucalypt samples.
source_citation: Burns, A. E., Taylor, G. S., Watson, D. M., & Cunningham, S. A. (2015). Diversity and host specificity of Psylloidea (Hemiptera) inhabiting box mistletoe, Amyema miquelii (Loranthaceae) and three of its host Eucalyptus species. Austral Entomology, 54(3), 306–314. doi: 10.1111/aen.12123

site_name: south-west slopes region of NSW (near Holbrook)
site_description: Woodland and forest have been extensively cleared for agriculture and remaining habitat is restricted to a series of disjunct remnants. measurement_remarks: Psylloids were collected from one sample of foliage per mistletoe plant or eucalypt tree.
methods: Insects were collected using a restricted canopy fogging technique (after Basset 1990), from plants of A. miquelii (n = 30) and three of its host tree species: E. polyanthemos (red box, n = 12), Eucalyptus melliodora (yellow box, n = 4) and Eucalyptus blakelyi (Blakely’s red gum, n = 3) using a trailer-mounted hydraulic bucket hoist (maximum height: 12 m above ground).
site_name: south-west slopes region of NSW (near Holbrook)
site_description: Woodland and forest have been extensively cleared for agriculture and remaining habitat is restricted to a series of disjunct remnants. At five sites of remnant grassy box woodland, 4–18 hectares in size and located 2–23 km apart (i.e. sites 1–5 in Burns et al. 2011). These sites were surrounded by grazed pastures or crops on privately owned land. The remnant woodlands were dominated by Eucalyptus polyanthemos (red box), which is the primary host of A. miquelii in the region. At least 40 individual A. miquelii occurred at each site.
plant_relation_description: host plant species; No particular host plant species preference for the psylloid species, as demonstrated by no significance (p>0.05) in indicated host of the psylloid species, based on the abundance (density of individuals per square-metre leaf area) and frequency of the species in the mistletoe and eucalypt samples.
source_citation: Burns, A. E., Taylor, G. S., Watson, D. M., & Cunningham, S. A. (2015). Diversity and host specificity of Psylloidea (Hemiptera) inhabiting box mistletoe, Amyema miquelii (Loranthaceae) and three of its host Eucalyptus species. Austral Entomology, 54(3), 306–314. doi: 10.1111/aen.12123

source_citation: Burckhardt, D., Farnier, K., Queiroz, D., Taylor, G., & Steinbauer, M. (2013). Ctenarytaina bipartita sp n. (Hemiptera, Psylloidea), a new eucalypt psyllid from Southeast Australia. Zootaxa, 3613, 589–596. doi: 10.11646/zootaxa.3613.6.5

methods: followed psyllids on 28 infested branchlets on seven trees of each species over a period of five months from October 2011 (second month of the austral spring) until February 2012 (last month of the austral summer). To provide sufficient time for appreciable branchlet extension and associated expansion of new leaves, psyllid surveys and leaf measurements occurred at monthly intervals.
site_description: Site 254 m a.s.l.; The canopies of E. kitsoniana comprised only 5-10% juvenile foliage (range in tree height in October 2.2 to 4.3 m).
source_citation: Steinbauer, M. J. (2013). Shoot Feeding as a Nutrient Acquisition Strategy in Free-Living Psylloids. PLOS ONE, 8(10), e77990. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0077990

methods: followed psyllids on 28 infested branchlets on seven trees of each species over a period of five months from October 2011 (second month of the austral spring) until February 2012 (last month of the austral summer). To provide sufficient time for appreciable branchlet extension and associated expansion of new leaves, psyllid surveys and leaf measurements occurred at monthly intervals.
site_description: Site 271 m a.s.l.; The canopies of E. globulus comprised 95-100% juvenile foliage (range in tree height in October 1.4 to 2.9 m).
associated_plant_taxa: Eucalyptus globulus subsp. bicostata, Eucalyptus pseudoglobulus

site_fire_impact: Site burned during a January 2003 bushfire. When revisited in September 2003 the termite mounds that the bees nest in were active but there were no Daviesia or Leioproctus (Leioproctus) nigrofulvus bees active. When revisited again in October-November 2008, Daviesia bloom was widespread but L. nigrofulvus was still not found despite other bees seen on the Daviesia flowers.
plant_relation_description: are oligolectic on flowers in the family, at this site only forages on Daviesia
fauna_relation_description: the bee nests exclusively in the subterranean mounds of Coptotermes lacteus in forest with an understorey of Daviesia
source_citation: Maynard, G., & Rao, S. (2010). The solitary bee, Leioproctus (Leioproctus) nigrofulvus (Cockerell 1914) (Hymenoptera: Colletidae), in SE Australia: Unique termite-mound-nesting behavior and impacts of bushfires on local populations. The Pan-Pacific Entomologist, 86(1), 14â€“19.

measurement_remarks: Acizzia solanicola, recorded from six host species in four genera, represents a rather broad host range across the Solanaceae

methods: Insects were collected using a restricted canopy fogging technique (after Basset 1990), from plants of A. miquelii (n = 30) and three of its host tree species: E. polyanthemos (red box, n = 12), Eucalyptus melliodora (yellow box, n = 4) and Eucalyptus blakelyi (Blakely’s red gum, n = 3) using a trailer-mounted hydraulic bucket hoist (maximum height: 12 m above ground).
site_name: south-west slopes region of NSW (near Holbrook)
site_description: Woodland and forest have been extensively cleared for agriculture and remaining habitat is restricted to a series of disjunct remnants. At five sites of remnant grassy box woodland, 4–18 hectares in size and located 2–23 km apart (i.e. sites 1–5 in Burns et al. 2011). These sites were surrounded by grazed pastures or crops on privately owned land. The remnant woodlands were dominated by Eucalyptus polyanthemos (red box), which is the primary host of A. miquelii in the region. At least 40 individual A. miquelii occurred at each site.
plant_relation_description: host plant species; Amyema miquelii on Eucalyptus polyanthemos; Amyema miquelii is the significant (p<0.05) indicated host of the psylloid species, based on the abundance (density of individuals per square-metre leaf area) (n=30) and frequency of the species in the mistletoe and eucalypt samples (n=19).
source_citation: Burns, A. E., Taylor, G. S., Watson, D. M., & Cunningham, S. A. (2015). Diversity and host specificity of Psylloidea (Hemiptera) inhabiting box mistletoe, Amyema miquelii (Loranthaceae) and three of its host Eucalyptus species. Austral Entomology, 54(3), 306–314. doi: 10.1111/aen.12123

plant_relation_description: host plant species; Allocasuarina luehmannii (Miq.) L. Johnson, C. cunninghamiana Miq. and A. cristata Miq. are unlikely hosts: where these hosts were recorded (see label data), trees were ornamentals in close proximity in an arboretum. In each case very few insect specimens were collected, yet they were abundant on neighbouring trees of A. verticillata (GST, personal observation).
